segment.source: A good UWP game supports a broad variety of interfaces.
segment.target: A good UWP game supports a broad variety of interfaces.

segment.source: A potential player might have Windows 10 on a tablet with no physical buttons, or a media PC with an Xbox controller attached, or the latest desktop gaming rig with a high-performance mouse and gaming keyboard.

segment.source: Common control behaviors
segment.target: Common control behaviors

segment.source: Touch controls and mouse/keyboard controls have a very similar core implementation.
segment.target: Touch controls and mouse/keyboard controls have a very similar core implementation.

segment.source: In a UWP app, a pointer is simply a point on the screen.
segment.target: In a UWP app, a pointer is simply a point on the screen.

segment.source: You can move it by sliding the mouse or sliding your finger on the touch screen.
segment.target: You can move it by sliding the mouse or sliding your finger on the touch screen.

segment.source: As a result, you can register for a single set of events, and not worry about whether the player is using a mouse or a touch screen to move and press the pointer.
segment.target: As a result, you can register for a single set of events, and not worry about whether the player is using a mouse or a touch screen to move and press the pointer.

segment.source: When the MoveLookController class in the game sample is initialized, it registers for four pointer-specific events and one mouse-specific event:
segment.target: When the MoveLookController class in the game sample is initialized, it registers for four pointer-specific events and one mouse-specific event:

segment.target: CoreWindow::PointerPressed.

segment.source: The left or right mouse button was pressed (and held), or the touch surface was touched.
segment.target: The left or right mouse button was pressed (and held), or the touch surface was touched.

segment.target: The mouse moved, or a drag action was made on the touch surface.

segment.target: The left mouse button was released, or the object contacting the touch surface was lifted.

segment.target: Windows::Devices::Input::MouseMoved.

segment.source: In the game sample, the MoveLookController class has three controller-specific states, regardless of the control type:
segment.target: In the game sample, the MoveLookController class has three controller-specific states, regardless of the control type:

segment.source: None.
segment.target: None.

segment.source: This is the initialized state for the controller.
segment.target: This is the initialized state for the controller.

segment.source: The game is not anticipating any controller input.
segment.target: The game is not anticipating any controller input.

segment.source: WaitForInput.
segment.target: WaitForInput.

segment.source: The game is paused and is waiting for the player to continue.
segment.target: The game is paused and is waiting for the player to continue.

segment.source: Active.
segment.target: Active.

segment.source: The game is running, processing player input.
segment.target: The game is running, processing player input.

segment.source: The Active state is the state when the player is actively playing the game.
segment.target: The Active state is the state when the player is actively playing the game.

segment.source: During this state, the MoveLookController instance is processing input events from all enabled input devices and interpreting the player's intentions based on the aggregated event data.
segment.target: During this state, the MoveLookController instance is processing input events from all enabled input devices and interpreting the player's intentions based on the aggregated event data.

segment.source: As a result, it updates the velocity and look direction (the view plane normal) of the player's view and shares the updated data with the game after Update is called from the game loop.
segment.target: As a result, it updates the velocity and look direction (the view plane normal) of the player's view and shares the updated data with the game after Update is called from the game loop.

segment.source: Be aware that the player can take more than one action at the same time.
segment.target: Be aware that the player can take more than one action at the same time.

segment.source: For example, he or she could be firing spheres while moving the camera.
segment.target: For example, he or she could be firing spheres while moving the camera.

segment.source: All of these inputs are tracked in the Active state, with different pointer IDs corresponding to different pointer actions.
segment.target: All of these inputs are tracked in the Active state, with different pointer IDs corresponding to different pointer actions.

segment.source: This is necessary because from a player's perspective, a pointer event in the firing rectangle is different from one in the move rectangle or in the rest of the screen.
segment.target: This is necessary because from a player's perspective, a pointer event in the firing rectangle is different from one in the move rectangle or in the rest of the screen.

segment.source: When a PointerPressed event is received, the MoveLookController obtains the pointer ID value created by the window.
segment.target: When a PointerPressed event is received, the MoveLookController obtains the pointer ID value created by the window.

segment.source: The pointer ID represents a specific type of input.
segment.target: The pointer ID represents a specific type of input.

segment.source: For example, on a multi-touch device, there may be several different active inputs at the same time.
segment.target: For example, on a multi-touch device, there may be several different active inputs at the same time.

segment.source: The IDs are used to keep track of which input the player is using.
segment.target: The IDs are used to keep track of which input the player is using.

segment.source: If one event is in the move rectangle of the touch screen, a pointer ID is assigned to track any pointer events in move rectangle.
segment.target: If one event is in the move rectangle of the touch screen, a pointer ID is assigned to track any pointer events in move rectangle.

segment.source: Other pointer events in the fire rectangle are tracked separately, with a separate pointer ID.
segment.target: Other pointer events in the fire rectangle are tracked separately, with a separate pointer ID.

segment.source: (We talk about this some more in the section on touch controls.)
segment.target: (We talk about this some more in the section on touch controls.)

segment.source: Input from the mouse has yet another ID and is also handled separately.
segment.target: Input from the mouse has yet another ID and is also handled separately.

segment.source: After the pointer events have been mapped to a specific game action, it's time to update the data the MoveLookController object shares with the main game loop.
segment.target: After the pointer events have been mapped to a specific game action, it's time to update the data the MoveLookController object shares with the main game loop.

segment.source: When called, the Update method in the game sample processes the input and updates the velocity and look direction variables (m\_velocity and m\_lookdirection), which the game loop then retrieves by calling the public Velocity and LookDirection methods on the MoveLookController instance.
segment.target: When called, the Update method in the game sample processes the input and updates the velocity and look direction variables (m\_velocity and m\_lookdirection), which the game loop then retrieves by calling the public Velocity and LookDirection methods on the MoveLookController instance.

segment.source: The game loop can test to see if the player is firing by calling the IsFiring method on the MoveLookController instance.
segment.target: The game loop can test to see if the player is firing by calling the IsFiring method on the MoveLookController instance.

segment.source: The MoveLookController checks to see if the player has pressed the fire button on one of the three input types.
segment.target: The MoveLookController checks to see if the player has pressed the fire button on one of the three input types.

segment.source: If the player moves the pointer outside the main window of the game, or presses the pause button (the P key or the Xbox controller start button), the game must be paused.
segment.target: If the player moves the pointer outside the main window of the game, or presses the pause button (the P key or the Xbox controller start button), the game must be paused.

segment.source: The MoveLookController registered the press, and informs the game loop when it calls the IsPauseRequested method.
segment.target: The MoveLookController registered the press, and informs the game loop when it calls the IsPauseRequested method.

segment.source: At that point, if IsPauseRequested returns true, the game loop then calls WaitForPress on the MoveLookController to move the controller into the WaitForInput state.
segment.target: At that point, if IsPauseRequested returns true, the game loop then calls WaitForPress on the MoveLookController to move the controller into the WaitForInput state.

segment.source: Then, the MoveLookController waits for the player to select one of the menu items to load, continue, or exit the game, and stop processing gameplay input events until it returns to the Active state.
segment.target: Then, the MoveLookController waits for the player to select one of the menu items to load, continue, or exit the game, and stop processing gameplay input events until it returns to the Active state.

segment.source: Implementing relative mouse controls
segment.target: Implementing relative mouse controls

segment.source: If mouse movement is detected, we want use that movement to determine the new pitch and yaw of the camera.
segment.target: If mouse movement is detected, we want use that movement to determine the new pitch and yaw of the camera.

segment.source: We do that by implementing relative mouse controls, where we handle the relative distance the mouse has moved—the delta between the start of the movement and the stop—as opposed to recording the absolute x-y pixel coordinates of the motion.
segment.target: We do that by implementing relative mouse controls, where we handle the relative distance the mouse has moved—the delta between the start of the movement and the stop—as opposed to recording the absolute x-y pixel coordinates of the motion.

segment.source: To do that, we obtain the changes in the X (the horizontal motion) and the Y (the vertical motion) coordinates by examining the MouseDelta::X and MouseDelta::Y fields on the Windows::Device::Input::MouseEventArgs::MouseDelta argument object returned by the MouseMoved event.
segment.target: To do that, we obtain the changes in the X (the horizontal motion) and the Y (the vertical motion) coordinates by examining the MouseDelta::X and MouseDelta::Y fields on the Windows::Device::Input::MouseEventArgs::MouseDelta argument object returned by the MouseMoved event.

segment.source: But the movement on the stick in a specific direction must register as larger than the radius of the dead zone; otherwise, nothing will happen.

segment.source: This dead zone radius is necessary to present "drifting," which is when the controller picks up minute movements from the player's thumb as it rests on the stick.
